ALPHA: The first letter of the Greek alphabet.
AARON: Meaning mountaineer, or mountain of strength, illuminator.
ABANA: Stony, the chief river of Damascus.
ABASED: To make or bring low; to humble.
ABBA: Term expressing warm affection and son/daughter confidence. It has no perfect equivalent in english.
ABEDNEGO: Meaning: servant of Nego, or servant of light.
ABEL:
Meaning: breath, or vanity;
Place name meaning: a grassy place, a meadow.
ABEZ: A town in the tribe of Issachar.
ABIA: My father is the Lord, the Greek form of the Hebrew Abijah, or Abijam (Matthew 1:7), instead of Abiah (1 Chronicles 7:8). In Luke 1:5, the name refers to the head of the eighth of the twenty-four courses into which David divided the priests (1 Chronicles 24:10).
ABIATHAR: Father of abundance, or my father excels.
ABIB: An ear of corn, the month of newly-ripened grain; the first of the Jewish ecclesiastical year, and the seventh of the civil year. It began about the time of the vernal equinox, on 21st March. It was called Nisan, after the Captivity
ABIGAIL: Father (i.e., leader) of the dance, or of joy.
ABIHU: Father of Him; i.e., worshipper of God,
ABIJAH: Father (i.e., possessor or worshipper) of Jehovah.
ABIMELECH:
My father a king, or father of a king.
A common name of the Philistine kings, as Pharaoh was of the Egyptian kings.
ABISHAI: Father of (i.e., desirous of) a gift.
ABJECTS: The translation of a Hebrew word meaning smiters; probably, in allusion to the tongue, slanderers.
ABOMINATION: Something morally or ritually disgusting, loathsome, or repellent
ACHISH: Angry, perhaps only a general title of royalty applicable to the Philistine kings.
ADJURE: To appeal to earnestly; to command.
ADMONITION: Gentle reproof; counseling against a fault; instruction in duties; caution; direction.
ADULTERY:
Conjugal infidelity. An adulterer was a man who had illicit intercourse with a married or a betrothed woman, and such a woman was an adulteress.
Intercourse between a married man and an unmarried woman was fornication.
AFFINITY: Relationship by alliance or by marriage.
AGAR: Another name for Hagar, Sarah's maid.
AGUE: A fever; an inflammatory or burning fever accompanied with shivering.
ALABASTER: These boxes were made from a stone found near Alabastron in Egypt.
ALLELUIA: The Greek form of the Hebrew Hallelujah = Praise ye Jehovah
ALOOF: At a distance, but within view.
ALTAR: (Hebrews mizbe’ah, from a word meaning “to slay”), any structure of earth or unwrought stone on which sacrifices were offered.
AMBASSAGE: A group of aged, high ranking men.
AMEN:
True; Firm (faithful; reliable);
"that which is true," "truth,"
(It is a Hebrew word: "אָמֵן" āmēn)
In Isaiah 65:16, it is translated as "the God of truth," which in Hebrew is "the God of Amen."
It is frequently used by the Lord Jesus Christ to give emphasis to his words, where it is translated "verily." ("truly")
AMORITES: Highlanders, or hillmen. The name given to the descendants of one of the sons of Canaan.
ANISE: Plant; commonly known by the name of Dill.
ANOINT: Apply perfumed oil to a person or object as a symbol of consecration, blessing, or empowerment.
ANOINTED: Person or object that has been consecrated or set apart for a divine purpose.
ANOINTING: The practice of applying perfumed oil to a person or object as a symbol of consecration, blessing, or empowerment.
ANTICHRIST: Against Christ, or an opposition Christ, a rival Christ.
ANTONIA: A fortress in Jerusalem, at the north-west corner of the temple area.
ANVIL: The rendering of the Hebrew word beaten.
APOLLONIA: A city of Macedonia between Amphipolis and Thessalonica.
APOLLYON: Destroyer. It is the Greek translation of the Hebrew Abaddon.
APOSTLE: A person sent by another; a messenger; envoy.
APOSTLES: People sent by another; messengers; envoys.
APPLE: The pupil of the eye. (Hebrews tappuah, meaning “fragrance”). Probably the apricot or quince.
ARABIA: Arid, an extensive region in the south-west of Asia.
ARCTURUS: A bright star; A cluster of stars.
ARTIFICER: A person engaged in any kind of manual occupation
ASHTORETH: The moon goddess of the Phoenicians.
ASP: A snake, serpent; probably the Egyptian cobra
ASSWAGED: To settle down; subside; hold back.
ASSYRIA: The name derived from the city Asshur on the Tigris.
ATONEMENT: at-one-ment, i.e., the state of being at one or being reconciled
BACKSLIDE: To draw back or apostatize in matters of religion.
BAKEMEATS: The works of a baker; such as biscuits and cakes.
BALM: A medicine; gum/rosin from a bush or a tree.
BANNER: A type of flag; a military ensign
BANQUET: A feast provided for the entertainment of a company of guests
BANQUETING: A feast; luxurious living; rich entertainment.
BAPTIZE: <dt>1.</dt><dd>To dip a thing into an element or liquid.</dd><dt>2.</dt><dd>To put an element or liquid over or on something.</dd>
BAPTIZED: <dt>1.</dt><dd>Dipped a thing into an element or liquid.</dd><dt>2.</dt><dd>Had put an element or liquid over or on something.</dd>
BAPTIZING: <dt>1.</dt><dd>Dipping a thing into an element or liquid.</dd><dt>2.</dt><dd>Putting an element or liquid over or on something.</dd>
BAPTISM: <dt>1.</dt><dd>To be dipped into an element or liquid.</dd><dt>2.</dt><dd>To have an element or liquid put over or on something.</dd>
BARBARIANS: People of other nations or people of other nations that speak a different language
BARKED: To remove skin or bark from.
BASE:
noun:
The bottom of any thing
adjective:
Of low station; Lowly; meek.
BATH: <dt>1.</dt><dd>A liquid measurement. Approx. 28.6 litres or 7 wine/US gallons and 4.5 pints.</dd><dt>2.</dt><dd>Names beginning: "Bath-" meaning "daughter of"<?dd>
BATHS:
A liquid measurement.
One bath equals Approx. 28.6 litres or 7 wine/US gallons and 4.5 pints.
BATTLEMENT:
A parapet wall or balustrade;
A low wall built around the roofs of the houses to prevent people from falling off.
BATTLEMENTS:
A parapet wall or balustrade;
A low wall built around the roofs of the houses to prevent people from falling off.
BEDSTEAD: A frame for supporting a bed
BEELZEBUB:
The name given to Satan.
It is probably from the Hebrew "Ba'al Zebub", the god of Ekron, meaning "the lord of flies," or, as others think, "the lord of dung," or "the dung-god."
BEHEMOTH: Possibly a water-ox or a hippopotamus.
BELIED: To lie against; to speak falsely.
BELLY:
Stomach; abdomen;
The word can be used symbolically for the heart
Philippians 3:19 and Romans 16:18
Carnal affections; fleshly desires.
BERYL: A precious stone; probably brought from Tarshish.
BESOM: A broom or sweep; of the sweeping away, the utter ruin, of Babylon
BESTEAD: To oppress, or be in circumstances of hardship
BETHINK: Lay it to heart; consider and repent.
BETROTH: To promise by one’s truth.; To be engaged.
BEULAH:
Meaning: Married.
is used metaphorically as the name of Judea: "Thy land shall be married," i.e., favoured and blessed of the Lord.
BEWAIL: Act of expressing deep sorrow or lamentation, often accompanied by weeping or mourning.
BEWAILED: Act of expressing deep sorrow or lamentation, often accompanied by weeping or mourning.
BEWAILETH: Act of expressing deep sorrow or lamentation, often accompanied by weeping or mourning.
BEWRAY: To reveal or disclose; an old English word equivalent to "betray".
BEWRAYETH: To reveal or disclose; an old English word equivalent to "betray".
BEWITCHED: To fascinate; to mislead with words.
BIER: The frame on which dead bodies were conveyed to the grave.
BILLOWS: A swelling or heap of water.
BIT: The curb put into the mouths of horses to restrain them.
BITTER: Symbolical of affliction, misery, and servitude.
BITTERNESS: Symbolical of affliction, misery, and servitude.
BLAINS: A kind of elephantiasis, producing burning ulcers.
BLASPHEME:
Speaking evil of God.
An indignity offered to God by words or writing; reproachful, contemptuous or irreverent words uttered disrespectfully against Jehovah.
BLASPHEMETH:
Speaking evil of God.
An indignity offered to God by words or writing; reproachful, contemptuous or irreverent words uttered disrespectfully against Jehovah.
BLASPHEMY:
Speaking evil of God.
An indignity offered to God by words or writing; reproachful, contemptuous or irreverent words uttered disrespectfully against Jehovah.
BLESSED: Signifies invoking divine favor, strength, and protection.
BOLLED:
Meaning: "swollen or podded for seed"
"was in bloom," which is the more probable rendering of the Hebrew word.
BOOTH: A hut made of the branches of a tree.
BOOTHS: Huts made from the branches of trees.
BOOTY: Captives or cattle or objects of value taken in war.
BOSSES: Circular swelling, mid-part of a shield.
BOX: <dt>1.</dt><dd>Flask, bottle or vial.</dd><dt>2.</dt><dd>Box tree: perhaps a species of cedar.<dd>
BRASS:
Probably copper, possibly bronze.
(Brass was invented in the 13th century).
BRAVERY: An old English word meaning comeliness or beauty.
BRAWLER: An angry contender; one who disputes with heat or bad temper; as a noisy contentious wrangler
BRAY: <dt>1.</dt><dd>To make a harsh sound, as of a donkey; a harsh grating sound</dd><dt>2.</dt>To pound, beat or grind small;</dd>
BRAYED: To make harsh sounds, as of a donkey's bray; to groan, wail; make a foul noise.
BREACH: The act of breaking; or state of being broken; a rupture; a break; a gap;
BREACHES:
breakages; ruptures; gaps.
Judges 5:17 :
A bay or harbour
(break or gap in coastline)
BREASTPLATE: <dt>1.</dt><dd>An ornament covering the breast (chest) of the high priest.</dd><dt>2.</dt><dd>Armour that protected the breast (chest).</dd>
BREECHES: Linen pants, reaching from the waist to a little above the knee
BRIGANDINE: Coat of armor; or habergeon; (chain mail shirt).
BRIGANDINES: Coats of armor; or habergeon; (chain mail shirts).
BRIMSTONE:
Meaning: "Burning stone".
Also known as Sulphur.
An inflammable mineral substance, yellow in colour.
BROIDED:
braided.
To weave or infold three or more strands to form one.
BROIDERED: To add imagery to cloth by needle work
BROOD:
Offspring;
A hatch; the young birds hatched at once;
BRUTISH:
Like a brute or beast;
stupid; savage; carnal; Ignorant; uncivilized; untaught.
BUCKLER:
A portable shield.
The buckler often was four feet long, and covered the whole body.
1 Chronicles 12:8 :
A lance or spear; improperly rendered "buckler" in the Authorized Version ( as per "Easton's Bible Dictionary").
BUCKLERS:
Portable shields.
Bucklers were often four feet long, and covered the whole body.
BUFFET: To assault; strike with the hand or fist; to contend against;
BULLOCK:
Bull; cow; ox;
Generic name for horned cattle.
Judges 6:25 : Bull offered in sacrifice
BULLOCKS:
Bulls; cows; oxen;
Generic name for horned cattle.
Isaiah 34:7 :
Bulls offered in sacrifice
BULWARKS:
Defensive structures;
Something that protects from a dangerous or unpleasant situation
BUTTOCKS:
Person's bottom;
The seat; the rear end.
CAB: A dry measurement. Approx. 1.56 litres or  3.33 wine/US pints.
CABINS:
Cells.
Arched vaults or recesses off a passage or room; cells for the closer confinement of prisoners.
CALDRON: A large, round, usually metal container for cooking in.
CALDRONS: large, round, usually metal containers for cooking in.
CALKERS: Workmen skilled in stopping (strenghtening or waterproofing) the seams of the deck or sides of vessels
CANDLESTICK:
Lampstand.
An object that holds a candle
CANKER: A gangrene or mortification which gradually spreads over the whole body.
CANKERWORM:
Hebrew: yelek
"the licking locust," which licks up the grass of the field; probably the locust at a certain stage of its growth, just as it emerges from the caterpillar state.
CARBUNCLE: A red gem; precious stone; red emerald
CARBUNCLES:
Red gems; precious stones; red emeralds
Hebrew: 'ekdah
used in the prophetic description of the glory and beauty of the mansions above.
CARNAL: Relating to the physical feelings and wants of the body.
CASEMENT: A barrier of open-work (lattice) placed before windows; an opening through which cool air is admitted.
CAUL:
Hebrew: yothe'reth; i.e., "something redundant"
The membrane which covers the upper part of the liver.
Hosea 13:8 :
Hebrew: seghor; i.e., "an enclosure"
The pericardium, or parts about the heart, is meant.
CAULS: Network (openwork fabric) caps to contain the hair, worn by females. Others explain it as meaning "wreaths worn round the forehead, reaching from one ear to the other."
CENSER: A small portable vessel of metal fitted to receive burning coals from the altar, and on which the incense for burning was sprinkled.<hr><dt>Hebrews 9:4 :</dt><dd>probably means the "altar of incense."</dd>
CENSERS: Small portable vessels of metal fitted to receive burning coals from the altar, and on which the incense for burning was sprinkled.
CENTURION: A Roman officer in command of a hundred men.<hr>"The centurions mentioned in the New Testament are uniformly spoken of in terms of praise, whether in the Gospels or in the Acts. It is interesting to compare this with the statement of Polybius (vi. 24), that the centurions were chosen by merit, and so were men remarkable not so much for their daring courage as for their deliberation, constancy, and strength of mind.", Dr. Maclear's N. T. Hist.
CENTURIONS: Roman officers in command of a hundred men.<hr>"The centurions mentioned in the New Testament are uniformly spoken of in terms of praise, whether in the Gospels or in the Acts. It is interesting to compare this with the statement of Polybius (vi. 24), that the centurions were chosen by merit, and so were men remarkable not so much for their daring courage as for their deliberation, constancy, and strength of mind.", Dr. Maclear's N. T. Hist.
CHAMBERLAIN:
Old testament
Eunuch, a confidential servant of the king.
New testament
Romans 16:23 : Here the word denotes the treasurer of the city, or the quaestor, as the Romans styled him.
Acts 12:20 : A post of honor which involved great intimacy and influence with the king.
CHAMBERLAINS: Eunuchs, confidential servants of the king.
CHAPITER: The ornamental head or capital of a pillar; i.e. the upper part.
CHAPITERS: The ornamental heads or capitals of the pillars; i.e. the upper parts.
CHARGER: A bowl or deep dish; a shallow vessel.
CHASTEN: To inflict trouble or pain for correction; to discipline.
CHASTENED: Inflicted with trouble or pain for correction; disciplined.
CHASTENEST: Inflicts trouble or pain for correction; disciplines.
CHASTENETH: Inflicts trouble or pain for correction; disciplines.
CHASTENING: Inflicting trouble or pain for correction; disciplining.
CHERUB:
The name of certain symbolical figures frequently mentioned in Scripture.
There is no hint given of their shape or form.
CHERUBIMS:
Plural of Cherub;
The name of certain symbolical figures frequently mentioned in Scripture.
There is no hint given of their shape or form.
CHRYSOPRASUS: Golden leek, a precious stone of the colour of leek's juice, a greenish-golden colour.
CHURCH:
Meaning: "Assembly called out by a legitimate authority".
Christian congregation.
CHURCHES:
Meaning: "Assemblies called out by a legitimate authority".
Christian congregations.
CHURLISH: A man that is coarse and ill-natured, or, as the word literally means, "hard".
CIRCUMSPECTLY:
Cautiously; with watchfulness every way;
With attention to guard against surprise or danger.
CISTERN: A receptacle for water, either supplied from an external spring or from rain-fall.
CISTERNS: Receptacles for water, either supplied from an external spring or from rain-fall.
CLAVE: <dt>1.</dt><dd>To split; to break through; tear.<dd><dt>2. Clave to, or Clave unto</dt><dd>To stick or hold firmly onto something.</dd>
CLEAVE: <dt>1.</dt><dd>To split; to break through; tear.<dd><dt>2. Cleave to, or Clave unto</dt><dd>To stick or hold firmly onto something.</dd>
CLEAVED: <dt>1.</dt><dd>To split; to break through; tear.<dd><dt>2. Cleaved to, or Claved unto</dt><dd>To stick or hold firmly onto something.</dd>
CLEAVETH: <dt>1.</dt><dd>To split; to break through; tear.<dd><dt>2. Cleaveth to, or Claveth unto</dt><dd>To stick or hold firmly onto something.</dd>
CLOKE: Upper garment, or robe, worn over the coat.
CLOVENFOOTED: Hooves split into two distinct parts.
COCKATRICE:
A viper; serpent.
It is generally supposed to denote the cerastes, or "horned viper," a very poisonous serpent about a foot long. Others think it to be the yellow viper (Daboia xanthina), one of the most dangerous vipers, from its size and its nocturnal habits.
COCKATRICES:
Vipers; serpents.
It is generally supposed to denote the cerastes, or "horned viper," a very poisonous serpent about a foot long. Others think it to be the yellow viper (Daboia xanthina), one of the most dangerous vipers, from its size and its nocturnal habits.
COCKLE:
An offensive weed.
Hebrew word (b'oshah) which means "offensive," "having a bad smell," referring to some weed perhaps which has an unpleasant odour. Or it may be regarded as simply any noisome weed, such as the "tares" or "darnel"
COMMEND: To formally praise or mention with approval someone or something
COMMENDED: Formally praised or mentioned with approval.
COMMENDETH: To formally praise or mention with approval someone or something
COMMUNICATE: To share or have things in common.
COMMUNICATED: Shared or had things in common.
COMPASS:
To surround; encircle.
"fetch a compass" means to take a roundabout (circular) route.
CONCISION: A term used by Paul contemptuously of those who were zealots for circumcision
CONCOURSE: A gathering; a crowd of people.
CONCUBINE:
A female conjugally united to a man, but in a relation inferior to that of a wife.
The difference probably lay in the absence of the right of the bill of divorce, without which the wife could not be refused support.
CONCUBINES:
Females conjugally united to a man, but in a relation inferior to that of a wife.
The difference probably lay in the absence of the right of the bill of divorce, without which the wife could not be refused support.
CONDESCEND: The voluntary act of lowering oneself to engage with someone of lower status, motivated by love, humility, and compassion rather than a loss of dignity.
CONEY:
Scientific name: Hyrax syriacus
Small animal, roughly the size of a domestic cat, very short tail and round ears.
CONFECTIONARIES: Those who make confections, i.e., those who make perfumes.
CONSECRATE: To devote or set apart for the worship or service of God.
CONSECRATED: Devoted or set apart to the worship or service of God.
CONSECRATION: The devoting or setting apart of anything to the worship or service of God.
CONSTRAIN: Compelling force or influence that directs or limits actions, thoughts, or feelings.
CONSTRAINED: Compelling force or influence that directs or limits actions, thoughts, or feelings.
CONSTRAINETH: Compelling force or influence that directs or limits actions, thoughts, or feelings.
CONSTRAINT: Compelling force or influence that directs or limits actions, thoughts, or feelings.
CONTEMN:
To despise; scorn.
It involves a deep-seated disrespect and a willful disregard for the value or authority of the person or thing.
CONTEMNED:
Despised; scorned.
It involves a deep-seated disrespect and a willful disregard for the value or authority of the person or thing.
CONTEMNETH:
Despises; scorns.
It involves a deep-seated disrespect and a willful disregard for the value or authority of the person or thing.
CONTEMPTIBLE: Deserving of disdain, scorn or disrespect.
CONTENTIOUS: A tendency to argue or provoke disputes.
CONTRARIWISE: An opposite or contrasting action, thought, or condition.
CONVERSATION:
Course of life; manner of life.
Philippians 1:27 and 3:20 :
A different Greek word is used. Here it means one's relations to a community as a citizen, i.e., citizenship.
CONVOCATION: A formal gathering or assembly of people.
CONVOCATIONS: Formal gatherings or assemblies of people.
CORMORANT: The etymology points to some diving (plunging) bird.
CORNET: A loud-sounding instrument, made of the horn of a ram or a chamois (sometimes of an ox).
COUCH: A seat for lying on or resting on.
COUCHED: A position of rest or lying down.
COUCHES: Seats for lying on or resting on.
COUCHINGPLACE: A place to rest or lie down.
COULTER: An agricultural instrument. It was the facing-piece of a plough
COUNTENANCE: <dt>1.</dt><dd>Appearance, especially the expression of the face.</dd><dt>2.</dt><dd>When applied to God, it signifies His presence, favor, and the manifestation of His character.<dd>
COUNTENANCES: Appearances, especially the expression of the face.
COVERT: A place of shelter, protection, or hiding.
COVET: An strong desire to possess something that belongs to another; To long after.
COVETED: An strong desire to possess something that belongs to another; To long after.
COVETOUS: A strong desire after the possession of worldly things. It assumes sometimes the more aggravated form of avarice, which is the mark of cold-hearted worldliness.
COVETOUSNESS: A strong desire after the possession of worldly things. It assumes sometimes the more aggravated form of avarice, which is the mark of cold-hearted worldliness.
CRACKNELS: A form of cake or biscuit.
CRIB: A feeding trough for animals, often made of wood or stone.
CRISPING: (Crisping Pins) Money bags or purses for females, highly ornamented, often made of silk inwrought with gold or silver.
CRUSE:
A small flask or cup for holding water or oil.
2 Kings 2:20 :
A platter or flat metal saucer is intended.
CUBIT:
A linear measurement; 1 Cubit = 2 spans, Approx. 55.6cm or 1 imperial foot and 9.888 inches.
Hebrew: ammah :
i.e. "mother of the arm," the fore-arm, is a word derived from the Latin cubitus, the lower arm.
CUBITS:
A linear measurement; 1 Cubit = 2 spans, Approx. 55.6cm or 1 imperial foot and 9.888 inches.
Hebrew: ammah :
i.e. "mother of the arm," the fore-arm, is a word derived from the Latin cubitus, the lower arm.
CUMBERED: A state of being burdened, distracted, or hindered by various concerns or activities.
CUMBERETH:
Burdens;
(depleting the soil and blocking the sunlight)?.
CUMMIN: A cultivated plant; It is an umbelliferous plant something like fennel. The seeds have a bitterish warm taste and an aromatic flavor.
CURIOUS:
Intricate, skillfully made, or crafted with great care and attention to detail.
Acts 19:19 :
Magical arts; jugglery practised by the Ephesian conjurers. Ephesus was noted for its wizard and the "Ephesian spells;" i.e., charms or scraps of parchment written over with certain formula, which were worn as a safeguard against all manner of evils. The more important and powerful of these charms were written out in books which circulated among the exorcists, and were sold at a great price.
DALE: "the king's dale": The name of a valley, the alternative for "the valley of Shaveh", near the Dead Sea.
DAMNATION:
Condemnation.
The state of eternal punishment and separation from God.
DANDLED:
Nurtured; comforted with and tender care.
Often associated with the imagery of a child being lovingly held and gently bounced on the knees.
DASH: A forceful or violent action, typically involving destruction or the breaking apart of objects or entities.
DASHED: Forceful or violent action, typically involving destruction or the breaking apart of objects or entities.
DASHETH: A forceful or violent actions, typically involving destruction or the breaking apart of objects or entities.
DAUB: Covering or coating a surface with a substance, typically for the purpose of concealment or protection.
DAUBED: The act of covering or coating a surface with a substance, typically for the purpose of concealment or protection.
DAYSMAN:
A judge; arbitrator; umpire.
This word is formed from the Latin diem dicere, i.e., to fix a day for hearing a cause. Such an one is empowered by mutual consent to decide the cause, and to "lay his hand", i.e., to impose his authority, on both, and enforce his sentence.
DAYSPRING: The dawn of the morning; daybreak.
DEACON:
From the Greek word diaconos, meaning a "runner," "messenger," "servant."
The office described by this title appears in the New Testament as a complementary relationship to the bishop. Its original meaning implied a helper, an assistant.
DEACONS:
From the Greek word diaconos, meaning a "runner," "messenger," "servant."
The office described by this title appears in the New Testament as a complementary relationship to the bishop. Its original meaning implied a helper, an assistant.
DEALS:
A dry measurement.
"deal" is used to describe a fraction of an ephah
One ephah equals one deal.
An ephah is approx. 29 litres or 3 imperial pecks and 3 pints.
DEGENERATE: Having fallen from a desirable state.
DERISION: Ridicule; mocking; laughing at enemies&apos threats.
DEVIL:
Satan or a demon (daemon)
From the Greek word diabolos, meaning slanderer or accuser.
The arch-enemy of man's spiritual interest. He is called also "the accuser of the brethen"
DIADEM:
The tiara of a king; turban; crown.
It is not known what the ancient Jewish "diadem" was.
DISCERN: To examine, prove or test; scrutinize.
DISCOMFITED: Defeated; thrown into a state of disorder.
DISDAINED: Act of regarding someone with contempt or scorn.
DISPENSATION: A commission to preach the gospel.
DISQUIET: Disturb; make restless; a state of unease.
DISQUIETNESS: Disturbance; restlessness; a state of uneasiness.
DISSEMBLED:
To use deceit; to feign.
The act of concealing one's true motives, feelings, or beliefs.
DISSEMBLERS:
Deceivers; hypocrites; pretenders.
Individuals who conceals their true motives, thoughts, or feelings under a false appearance.
DISSEMBLETH: Uses deceit; conceals behind a false appearance; pretends.
DISSIMULATION: Concealing one's true motives, thoughts, or feelings by pretense or deceit.
DOCTOR:
A teacher;
The Jewish doctors taught and disputed in synagogues, or wherever they could find an audience. Their disciples were allowed to propose to them questions. They assumed the office without any appointment to it. The doctors of the law were principally of the sect of the Pharisees.
DOCTORS:
Teachers;
The Jewish doctors taught and disputed in synagogues, or wherever they could find an audience. Their disciples were allowed to propose to them questions. They assumed the office without any appointment to it. The doctors of the law were principally of the sect of the Pharisees.
DOCTRINE: A belief or set of beliefs that are held and taught.
DOCTRINES: A set of beliefs that are held and taught.
DOTED: To have been excessively fond of someone or something, often to the point of foolishness or weakness.
DOTH:
does.
The third person singular present tense of the verb "do."
DOTING: Excessive affection or foolish infatuation, particularly when it leads to a departure from sound judgment or truth.
DRAGON:
Old Testament:
1.
The name of some unknown creature inhabiting desert places and ruins
2.
Some great sea monster or serpent
The Book of "The Revelation":
Metaphorically refers to "Satan."
DRAGONS: <dt>1.</dt><dd>The name of some unknown creatures inhabiting desert places and ruins</dd><dt>2.</dt><dd>Some great sea monsters or serpents</dd>
DRAUGHT:
"A place of sitting apart", i.e. A toilet; lavatory.
The Gospel According to St Luke
Draw in or pull in; haul.
DREGS: The lees (sediment) of wine which settle at the bottom of the vessel.
DROMEDARIES:
A camel.
It is distinguished from the camel only as a trained saddle-horse is distinguished from a cart-horse.
They were used for carrying burdens, and for riding
DROPSY:
An illness.
Possibly "edema" which is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the body's tissues, leading to swelling.
From the Greek word hydrops, which means "water".
DROSS: The impurities separated from silver in the process of melting.
DUKE:
This word is used to denote the chief of a tribe.
Derived from the Latin dux, meaning "a leader".
DUKES:
This word is used to denote the chiefs of tribes.
Derived from the Latin dux, meaning "a leader".
EARNEST:
Pledge.
Signifying the deposit paid by the purchaser on entering into an agreement for the purchase of anything.
EASTER:
Passover.
The festival of the Resurrection of Christ, which occured at the time of the Passover.
EDIFY:
To construct, build up or establish
Refers to the spiritual building up or strengthening of individuals
EFFEMINATE: Men having the qualities of the female sex; soft or delicate to an unmanly degree; tender; womanish;.
EL:
God.
Hebrew אֵל El: meaning God, mighty one
ELDER:
1.
Older; one who is greater in age.
2.
Hebrew זָקֵן meaning: "Old man".
Denoting people clothed with authority, and entitled to respect and reverence
In the New Testament Church the elders or presbyters were the same as the bishops. It was an office derived from the Jewish usage of elders or rulers of the synagogues.
ELDERS:
Hebrew זָקֵן meaning: "Old men".
Denoting people clothed with authority, and entitled to respect and reverence.
In the New Testament Church the elders or presbyters were the same as the bishops. It was an office derived from the Jewish usage of elders or rulers of the synagogues.
ELIAS: The Greek form of the Hebrew name Elijah.
ELISEUS: The Greek form of the Hebrew name Elisha.
EMERODS: Probably hemorrhiodal tumors, i.e. hemorrhoids or bleeding piles, are intended.
EMINENT: Something raised up high, or of high rank and status.
EMULATIONS: Jealousy that leads to rivalry and discord.
ENGINES: <dt>2 Chronicles 26:15</dt><dd>"inventions"; clever devices - indicating ingenuity.</dd><dt>Ezekiel 26:9</dt><dd>Inventions or devices(engines) for a battering-ram; beating of that which is in front.</dd>
ENGRAFTED: Metaphor of grafting in horticulture, where a branch or shoot is inserted into a different plant so that they grow together as one.
ENJOIN:
Command; charge.
Commands or instructions given by God, prophets, or leaders that are meant to be followed by the people.
ENJOINED:
Commanded; charged.
Commands or instructions given by God, prophets, or leaders that are meant to be followed by the people.
ENSIGN:
A banner; sign.
A figure or device of some kind elevated on a pole; usually a sacred emblem, such as an animal, a boat, or the king's name.
ENSIGNS:
Banners; signs.
A figure or device of some kind elevated on a pole; usually a sacred emblem, such as an animal, a boat, or the king's name.
ENSUE: To pursue after something with a sense of earnestness or diligence.
EPHAH: A volume measurement;<dt>Liquid:</dt><dd>Approx. 9.46 litres or 2.5 wine/US gallons</dd><dt>Dry volume:</dt><dd>Approx. 29 litres or 3 imperial pecks and 3 pints.<dd><hr>Ephah (with a capital "E"): name of a city or person.
EPHOD:
Priestly garment.
Consisted of two pieces, which hung from the neck, and covered both the back and front, above the tunic and outer garment. The two pieces were joined together over the shoulders.
EQUITY: Fairness, justice, and impartiality in judgment and behavior.
ERR: Stray,wander or deviate from what is correct or true.
ESAIAS: The Greek form of the Hebrew name Isaiah.
ESCHEW:
To avoid; turn aside from.
From old French eschever, "to flee from"
ESCHEWED:
Avoided; turned aside from.
"eschew" from old French eschever, "to flee from"
ESCHEWETH:
Avoids; turns aside from.
"eschew" from old French eschever, "to flee from"
ESPOUSED: Betrothed or engaged to be married.
ESPIED: To have perceived with the eyes.
EUNUCH:
Literally bed-keeper or chamberlain, employed in royal courts.
Not necessarily in all cases one who was mutilated (castrated), although the practice of employing such mutilated persons in Oriental courts was common.
EUNUCHS:
Literally bed-keepers or chamberlains, employed in royal courts.
Not necessarily in all cases one who was mutilated (castrated), although the practice of employing such mutilated persons in Oriental courts was common.
EUROCLYDON:
A furious, north-easterly wind.
A violent wind or hurricane, cyclone, on the Mediterranean, and very dangerous; now called the "Viento de Levante" or the "Levanter".
EVANGELIST:
A "publisher of glad tidings".
A missionary preacher of the gospel
EVANGELISTS:
"publishers of glad tidings".

EXECRATION: An object of cursing, loathing and detestation.
EXTOL: To lift up, esteem and praise with great admiration.
EXTOLLED: Lifted up, esteemed and praised with great admiration.
EXTORTION: Act of unlawfully obtaining gain through coercion, threats, or manipulation.
EXTORTIONER: One who unlawfully obtains gain through coercion, threats, or manipulation.
EXTORTIONERS: Those who unlawfully obtain gain through coercion, threats, or manipulation.
EYESERVICE: Service performed only while being watched.
FAMILIAR SPIRIT: Sorcerers or necormancers, who professed to call up the dead to answer questions, were said to have a "familiar spirit". Such a person was called by the Hebrews an 'ob, which properly means a leathern bottle; for sorcerers were regarded as vessels containing the inspiring demon. This Hebrew word was equivalent to the Puthó (Pytho meaning: Python, a mythical serpent slain by Apollo) of the Greeks, and was used to denote both the person and the spirit which possessed him. The word "familiar" is from the Latin familiaris, meaning a "household servant," and was intended to express the idea that sorcerers had spirits as their servants ready to obey their commands.
FAMILIAR SPIRITS: Sorcerers or necormancers, who professed to call up the dead to answer questions, were said to have a "familiar spirit". Such a person was called by the Hebrews an 'ob, which properly means a leathern bottle; for sorcerers were regarded as vessels containing the inspiring demon. This Hebrew word was equivalent to the Puthó (Pytho meaning: Python, a mythical serpent slain by Apollo) of the Greeks, and was used to denote both the person and the spirit which possessed him. The word "familiar" is from the Latin familiaris, meaning a "household servant," and was intended to express the idea that sorcerers had spirits as their servants ready to obey their commands.
FAMISHED:
An extreme of lack of sustenance.
No physical or spiritual food.
THE FAN:
An agricultural tool;
A winnowing-shovel , with which grain was thrown up against the wind to be cleansed from the chaff and straw.
WHOSE FAN:
fan: An agricultural tool;
A winnowing-shovel , with which grain was thrown up against the wind to be cleansed from the chaff and straw.
FARTHING:
Very small amount of money.
Matthew 10:29 :
Greek assarion, which was a Roman coin equal to a tenth of a denarius or a tenth of a Greek drachma.

Matthew 5:26; Mark 12:42 :
Greek kodrantes (Quadrans), equal to two lepta, mites. The lepton (mite) was the very smallest copper coin.
FARTHINGS:
Very small amount of money.
Greek assarion,
Two Roman coins equal to a fifth of a denarius or a fifth of a Greek drachma.

20 fathoms = Approx 37 metres
